column2: Wide Receiver Is Not A Priority|“This Joe” believes there is nothing resembling the crater-sized hole on the Bucs’ roster than the one at inside linebacker. But a member of the PFF tribe seems to think otherwise. Zoltán Buday of the PFF tribe cobbled together a list of the highest priorities on each NFL team’s roster. He doesn’t see the Bucs going after an inside linebacker. Or a safety. Or a corner. Or even a pass rusher. In fact
column3: Buday doesn’t even think any defender is a priority. Instead
column4: Buday believes the Bucs should go after a receiver. Tampa Bay Buccaneers: Invest in a wide receiver Only two Tampa Bay wide receivers earned [strong reviews] in 2024 — Chris Godwin and Mike Evans. … However
column5: Godwin is coming off an injury and is expected to hit free agency next month
column6: while Evans will turn 32 before the start of the 2025 season. The Bucs also lacked youth at the position — Jalen McMillan was the team’s only receiver under 28 to log more than 300 snaps. [McMillan] showed improvement as the season progressed. Well
column7: McMillan showed more than just improvement. He looked like the stud many thought he would be based on how he stood out in training camp. In a vacuum
column8: Joe could sort of understand what Buday is suggesting. But it shouldn’t be a priority. Maybe a receiver in the third round isn’t an awful thing. “This Joe” believes the Bucs’ draft this spring should be straight-up all defenders. (The other Joe would die from a heart attack if this happened.) For now
column9: Joe is waiting to see what Bucs AC/DC-loving general manager Jason Licht and coach Todd Bowles come up with for an offensive coordinator. If the guy is a run-run-run-your-boat
column11: Joe then thinks there is a reasonalbe possibility Chris Godwin may not return. If the new offensive coordinator doesn’t want to pass much
column12: it’s then hard for the bean counters at One Buc Palace to justify paying two receivers $20 million each a season. In a big picture view
column13: Joe gets what Buday is suggesting
column14: especially when Mike Evans and Godwin will be 32 and 29
column15: respectively — geezers for NFL receivers. The Bucs do need another young receiver. But it surely isn’t a priority when the Bucs have more holes on defense than a slice of Swiss cheese.|2025-01-30 10:30:00|391|60|7|Zoltán Buday|Bucs should invest in young wide receiver.|5|Mixed opinions on WR draft pick

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/01/todd-bowles-has-graham-bartons-back/|Todd Bowles Has Graham Barton’s Back|Joe likes to say rookies play like rookies because they are rookies. But there is one Bucs rookie that Bucs coach Todd Bowles is confident will raise his game in 2025. Center Graham Barton sure showed promise that he could be one of the league’s better centers. But man
column2: he has to work on snaps. Sadly for the Bucs
column3: that nasty issue crept up at the worst time
column4: when the Bucs appeared on the doorstep of taking a lead in the wild card loss. Yes
column5: Joe knows Barton was trying to catch the Commandos offsides. But that earlier-than-expected snap screwed up the play
column7: and spooked Bowles to the point he instead chose to kick a game-tying field goal
column8: angering many Bucs fans. In his final media availability for the 2024 season
column9: Bowles heaped a lot of praise on Barton. “I liked the steadiness that Graham Barton showed as a rookie
column10: ” Bowles said. “Playing one of the toughest spots on the field
column11: going against a Pro Bowler almost every week and just doing his job and coming to work every day with a lunch pail attitude. “Making blitz adjustments and stunt adjustments aren’t easy for a first-year center.” Barton’s inexperience as a center showed. To be fair
column12: it wasn’t really that much worse than when Ali Marpet played center and even Ryan Jensen in his first Bucs season (2018). Those two guys could just about be counted on for one shaky snap a game. That’s about what Barton was doing. And he was only a rookie. column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/01/why-the-rush-to-extend-luke-goedeke/|Why The Rush To Extend Luke Goedeke?|Unless Bucs right tackle Luke Goedeke has been telling people off the record he’s going launch Operation Shutdown like left tackle Tristan Wirfs did last year
column2: Joe doesn’t understand the hyperventilating to extend Goedeke’s contract. Over at BSPN
column3: it seems to be a theme that Goedeke’s contract must be extended. Now. Why? Even Eagles fan Ben Solak has joined the parade. Big prediction for the offseason: A big extension will come down the mountain for Goedeke
column4: who has become a rock-solid right tackle opposite Tristan Wirfs and is approaching the final year of his rookie deal. Something in the range of the Spencer Brown deal (four years
column5: $72 million) would be more than deserved. And after Goedeke’s extension is signed
column6: the conversations with cornerback Zyon McCollum will begin. Unless Goedeke forces the issue — and he may — why spend money when you don’t have to? Perhaps Licht wants to rework Goedeke’s contract to make it team-friendly so Licht can go out in six weeks and buy some defenders when the free agency dinner bell rings. If that’s the angle
column7: OK. Joe gets that. Football is a violent game. What if Goedeke
column8: on the heels of an expensive new contract
column9: suffers a major injury or another concussion? (He missed four games with concussion this season.) Then the Bucs also would have to spend a lot of Team Glazer loot on a replacement. That’s a good way to screw up your salary cap. Yeah
column10: waiting until the last minute to re-sign Goedeke might cost extra Team Glazer loot in the long run. The good thing here is the salary cap
column13: Goedeke threatening Operation Shutdown is a real possibility. His current rookie contract expires after the 2025 season. Joe just doesn’t see the need to rush.
